pullRequest.body:
This PR defines the basic preliminaries for defining locally cartesian closed categories (LCCCs). In particular, using the calculus of mates we define certain natural isomorphisms involving `Over.star` and `Over.pullback` which will be crucial in defining the right adjoint to the pullback functor in the development of LCCCs.

---

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Just to mention that I have an old development of locally cartesian closed categories here: https://github.com/b-mehta/topos/blob/master/src/locally_cartesian_closed.lean, which you may like to look at too. (This development from 5 years ago is what gave rise to the current implementation of cartesian closed categories and of sheaves and sites in mathlib!) Note that this is Lean 3, and was written when has_finite_limits meant what would currently mean HasChosenFiniteLimits.

> Just to mention that I have an old development of locally cartesian closed categories here: https://github.com/b-mehta/topos/blob/master/src/locally_cartesian_closed.lean, which you may like to look at too. (This development from 5 years ago is what gave rise to the current implementation of cartesian closed categories and of sheaves and sites in mathlib!) Note that this is Lean 3, and was written when has_finite_limits meant what would currently mean HasChosenFiniteLimits.

Thanks @b-mehta, this is great, thanks for sharing! I wish I was aware of your repo when we did the formalization of LCCCs last summer at HIM.  And personally speaking, I wish we had a better infrastructure to make off-mathlib projects more prominent, for instance on the mathlib community website. 

Just quickly looking into your Lean 3 formalization, I think our implementations diverges in few regards. I think I put more primacy on working with pushforwards more directly since these are what I needed most for the polynomial functors. Also, in the summer project, I realized in some situations it is easier to prove LCCC structure from cartesian closeness of slices and in other cases, when the pushforwards are available we can obtain LCCC structures without using the API of Over categories which personally I am not a big fan of and its API somewhat distracting. Also, I think similar to [OverAdjunction](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/MorphismProperty/OverAdjunction.lean) it will be useful to have the API of `HasPushforwards` generalized to a class of morphisms with `MorphismProperty`, e.g. Conduché fibrations and tidy/proper geometric morphisms are examples of classes of exponential maps in non-LCCC categories, but nevertheless important. For me, exponentiable fibrations in non-LCCCs were important in the polynomial functor formalization.

I do like your definition of pushforward using the iterated slice construction. I think, if I do not misunderstand what you did, the idea is similar to `Comma.Over.Sections` in here: 
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21525/files#diff-be27792f64b32cb78937c6244c8d305283c48d5c725fff684bf1dc21882a9a32

where your `Pi_functor` is `sectionsFunctor` in above.

On a brief look the definition of pushforward does indeed look quite similar! I am not too surprised that our implementations differ, since we had very different goals in mind: mine was elementary and Grothendieck topos theory. I hope the final one works in both contexts! I'm happy to chat more about this elsewhere if it would be useful to you.

> On a brief look the definition of pushforward does indeed look quite similar! I am not too surprised that our implementations differ, since we had very different goals in mind: mine was elementary and Grothendieck topos theory. I hope the final one works in both contexts! I'm happy to chat more about this elsewhere if it would be useful to you.

Yes, agreed. I noticed your development of elementary topos theory is now being PR'd to mathlib4. I think it's important that the same formalism of LCCCs works for polynomial functors as well as for elementary toposes. My guess is that it does, since our definition of LCCC recaptures and is in fact equivalent to the usual definition of cartesian closed slices, but it allows the user the flexibility of using its two equivalent features: cartesian closed slices and having pushforwards along all morphisms. 
```
class LocallyCartesianClosed [HasFiniteWidePullbacks C] extends
     HasPushforwards C where
   /-- every slice category `Over I` is cartesian closed. This is filled in by default. -/
   cartesianClosedOver : Π (I : C), CartesianClosed (Over I) := HasPushforwards.cartesianClosedOver
```

Happy to chat further on Zulip/Zoom.

@joelriou @b-mehta 

Joël asked if for the purpose of a more focussed reviews, I could extract a PR mostly containing the first chunk of modifications. This is now done, and the PR message at the top is accordingly updated. In particular, there will be not changes to file `Equivalence` as I found a workaround to prove things without looking into the blackbox of `asEquivalence` and in particular its inverse. 

The next PR will define the section functor depending on the current PR! This will be used in the PR after that which adds the new folder `LocallyCartesianClosed` and the file `Basic` in that folder.

And then after that separate PRs for the following stuff:

1. Beck-Chevalley condition as a file in the folder `LocallyCartesianClosed`
2. LCCC structure on Types as a file in the folder `LocallyCartesianClosed`
3. LCCC structure on Presheaf Categories as a file in the folder `LocallyCartesianClosed`
4. Polyonomial functors
Could you add references to the math literature where these notations appear?

One canonical example would be 
> Nicola Gambino and Joachim Kock. Polynomial functors and polynomial monads. Mathematical Proceedings of the Cambridge Philosophical Society, 154(1):153–192, 2013.

(see pages 5 and 6 of https://arxiv.org/pdf/0906.4931). 

I can dd this reference either to `CategoryTheory.Adjunction.Over` where `Σ X Y` and `Δ X Y` are introduced or in `CategoryTheory.LocallyCartesianClosed.Basic` where `Π X Y` is introduced, or I can add the reference to both?

This should not be in this file, and I am quite sure we can avoid providing too much API for `Functor.asEquivalence`, which should be considered as a black box equivalence of categories with a prescribed `.functor` field.

In order to get more focussed reviews, could you extract a PR mostly containing the first chunk of modifications to this file `Adjunction.Over`. Actually, I am not completely convinced that some definitions (including existing ones) are in the right location.
Then, I would suggest you start with a PR which just moves the file `CategoryTheory.Comma.Over` to `Category.Comma.Over.Basic`, `Comma.OverClass` to `Comma.Over.OverClass`, and the existing content of `Adjunction.Over` to `Comma.Over.Pullback`.

Re reorganizing and moving `Over` files:  I very much agree with what you proposed. Then I do another PR about that.  

Re `Functor.asEquivalence`: I originally put them in `CategoryTheory.Equivalence` file, would that be a better choice? 

But mainly, in  LCCCs, we construct natural isomorphisms between pushforwards as mate of corresponding nat isos of left adjoints. The API 
```
Equivalence.asEquivalenceInverse (e : C ≌ D) :
     (e.functor).asEquivalence.inverse ≅ e.inverse := by
```      
was necessary to prove `star (⊤_ C) ≅ Functor.toOverTerminal C` using this mate philosophy which happens consistently in the LCCC development. 

It might be possible to not use this philosophy in constructing `star (⊤_ C) ≅ Functor.toOverTerminal C`. 

But, I think it might be useful to know in general that if promote an equivalence to an adjoint equivalence and the inverse `inv` remains the same as `inverse` of original equivalence. I couldn't prove this fact without `Equivalence.asEquivalenceInverse`, but maybe there is a way I missed.

Anyhow, I think the important point is the reorganization which I'll do after I wake up. :)

@joelriou Just to make sure I'm on the same page, after #21717, is the idea to make a new separate PR for the changes made to `Adjunction.Over` (or, `Comma.Over.Pullback` after  #21717)? This would include namespaces `Sigma`, `Reindex`, the section `BinaryProduct`, `TensorLeft` and new lemmas about `star`.

```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CategoryTheory): reorganizing Over categories

nodes.body: Just to mention that I have an old development of locally cartesian closed categories here: https://github.com/b-mehta/topos/blob/master/src/locally_cartesian_closed.lean, which you may like to look at too. (This development from 5 years ago is what gave rise to the current implementation of cartesian closed categories and of sheaves and sites in mathlib!) Note that this is Lean 3, and was written when has_finite_limits meant what would currently mean HasChosenFiniteLimits.

> Just to mention that I have an old development of locally cartesian closed categories here: https://github.com/b-mehta/topos/blob/master/src/locally_cartesian_closed.lean, which you may like to look at too. (This development from 5 years ago is what gave rise to the current implementation of cartesian closed categories and of sheaves and sites in mathlib!) Note that this is Lean 3, and was written when has_finite_limits meant what would currently mean HasChosenFiniteLimits.

Thanks @b-mehta, this is great, thanks for sharing! I wish I was aware of your repo when we did the formalization of LCCCs last summer at HIM.  And personally speaking, I wish we had a better infrastructure to make off-mathlib projects more prominent, for instance on the mathlib community website. 

Just quickly looking into your Lean 3 formalization, I think our implementations diverges in few regards. I think I put more primacy on working with pushforwards more directly since these are what I needed most for the polynomial functors. Also, in the summer project, I realized in some situations it is easier to prove LCCC structure from cartesian closeness of slices and in other cases, when the pushforwards are available we can obtain LCCC structures without using the API of Over categories which personally I am not a big fan of and its API somewhat distracting. Also, I think similar to [OverAdjunction](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/MorphismProperty/OverAdjunction.lean) it will be useful to have the API of `HasPushforwards` generalized to a class of morphisms with `MorphismProperty`, e.g. Conduché fibrations and tidy/proper geometric morphisms are examples of classes of exponential maps in non-LCCC categories, but nevertheless important. For me, exponentiable fibrations in non-LCCCs were important in the polynomial functor formalization.

I do like your definition of pushforward using the iterated slice construction. I think, if I do not misunderstand what you did, the idea is similar to `Comma.Over.Sections` in here: 
https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/21525/files#diff-be27792f64b32cb78937c6244c8d305283c48d5c725fff684bf1dc21882a9a32

where your `Pi_functor` is `sectionsFunctor` in above.

On a brief look the definition of pushforward does indeed look quite similar! I am not too surprised that our implementations differ, since we had very different goals in mind: mine was elementary and Grothendieck topos theory. I hope the final one works in both contexts! I'm happy to chat more about this elsewhere if it would be useful to you.

> On a brief look the definition of pushforward does indeed look quite similar! I am not too surprised that our implementations differ, since we had very different goals in mind: mine was elementary and Grothendieck topos theory. I hope the final one works in both contexts! I'm happy to chat more about this elsewhere if it would be useful to you.

Yes, agreed. I noticed your development of elementary topos theory is now being PR'd to mathlib4. I think it's important that the same formalism of LCCCs works for polynomial functors as well as for elementary toposes. My guess is that it does, since our definition of LCCC recaptures and is in fact equivalent to the usual definition of cartesian closed slices, but it allows the user the flexibility of using its two equivalent features: cartesian closed slices and having pushforwards along all morphisms. 
```
class LocallyCartesianClosed [HasFiniteWidePullbacks C] extends
     HasPushforwards C where
   /-- every slice category `Over I` is cartesian closed. This is filled in by default. -/
   cartesianClosedOver : Π (I : C), CartesianClosed (Over I) := HasPushforwards.cartesianClosedOver
```

Happy to chat further on Zulip/Zoom.

@joelriou @b-mehta 

Joël asked if for the purpose of a more focussed reviews, I could extract a PR mostly containing the first chunk of modifications. This is now done, and the PR message at the top is accordingly updated. In particular, there will be not changes to file `Equivalence` as I found a workaround to prove things without looking into the blackbox of `asEquivalence` and in particular its inverse. 

The next PR will define the section functor depending on the current PR! This will be used in the PR after that which adds the new folder `LocallyCartesianClosed` and the file `Basic` in that folder.

And then after that separate PRs for the following stuff:

1. Beck-Chevalley condition as a file in the folder `LocallyCartesianClosed`
2. LCCC structure on Types as a file in the folder `LocallyCartesianClosed`
3. LCCC structure on Presheaf Categories as a file in the folder `LocallyCartesianClosed`
4. Polyonomial functors

source.title: feat(CategoryTheory): Locally Cartesian Closed Categories (Sections Right Adjoint)
feat(CategoryTheory): Locally Cartesian Closed Categories (Beck-Chevalley Conditions)
